ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Weekly seminar with guest speakers

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a valuable understanding of the Northern Ireland conflict. This course was outstanding!

This class provided great insight into everything Ireland / Northern Ireland. Going into the class I had it in my mind that it would be mostly fixated on "the troubles" but that was actually only a small portion of the class, and it was amazing to see and learn so much about such a small region that has such a complex situation going on.
An in-depth knowledge of a very particular moment in history in Northern Ireland, as well as a great deal of insight via guest speakers that added an extra layer of value to our weekly discussions
We traced (almost) the entire lineage of the sectarian divide in Northern Ireland. Our study touched on history, political science, and sociology.
I got a much better sense of how to interview people and develop questions as our discussions played out (vs. the ones I had prepared)
Very thorough knowledge/background of the region and conflict as well as hearing from speakers with different experiences & perspectives
I learned a lot about the role of history and trauma in contemporary Northern Irish politics. I also learned a lot more about politics throughout the states and regions of the British Isles.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: All the guest speakers were super engaging and Bonnie was super great. The content was incredibly interesting and allowed for some really stimulating conversations. Weaknesses: The only weakness would be the lack of feedback throughout the course, we did not get grades back and so it is a bit hard to know exactly where we fall in terms of our performance.
Incredible, literally cannot be improved. Ideally, all courses at Yale should be taught this way.

One of the most engaging courses I've taken at Yale. Such great content, discussion, history, human stories, etc.. I would have appreciated either a clearly framework for the written work, or more consistent feedback.

I thought this course interview format worked superbly! One thing is that we sometimes struggled to have a discussion before guests arrived. One idea would be to adopt the twice-per-week, 1 hr 15 minute course scheduling option.
Professor Weir is amazing!! She is extremely intelligent and very willing to meet with and enhance students learning! Speakers were incredible as well!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual aspects of the course worked really well and actually made a lot of sense given that we would have likely been talking to guest speakers over Zoom anyway.
This course was very well executed and I didnt find any drawbacks to the virtual setting.

It was difficult to get in touch with the professor at times when it came to scheduling office hours / emails, but it wasn't too much of a bother. Breaking the seminar into three parts (a student presentation, discussion and a guest speaker) really helped fight "zoom fatigue" and keep students engaged.
I learned so much more from our responses and preparation each week than I would have from a single long paper. This was especially helpful during covid.
Still loved the seminar even though it was virtual

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! This course has been the most interesting and engaging class that I have taken at Yale and Bonnie is an absolute gem.
YES
Absolutely.

Yes, but they have to be committed to completing the readings, doing background research, and maintaining an interest in the course material throughout the semester. It is very easy to get left behind if you aren't paying attention, and doing work in preparation for the seminar occupied most of my Sunday afternoons and evenings. That being said, the quantity of assignments you actually do for this course is quite low - so you have some flexibility week-to-week if need be.
Absolutely would recommend. As with any seminar you get what you give, but it is very easy to put in the work here.
Certainly. This is fascinating on a content and theoretical level.
Yes!
Yes, its a special experience to be able to interact with those who have survived conflict and are working to move beyond the divisions it creates, both from an academic and human perspective.

extras.title:
HIST 245J 01/GLBL 289 01/PLSC 431 01
        War and Peace in N Ireland
